## Introduction

* One of the most prominent expressions of inequality is **spatial segregation** based on socio-economic (Jargowsky, 1996) and racial (Rugh & Massey, 2010) characteristics of residents

* Segregation is related to exclusion of poor neighborhoods from privileges and benefits, which violates widely shared norms of **equal opportunity and dignity of each person**

## Introduction

\begin{columns}

\begin{itemize}
\item Previous studies on spatial segregation mostly used census data and thus focused on measuring population distribution patterns in \textbf{residential space} (Dwyer, 2007; Massey and Denton, 1988; Vesselinov \textit{et al.}, 2007)
\item Nowadays it is acknowledged that segregation is also manifested in \textbf{other spheres and aspects of daily life} (Wissink \textit{et al.}, 2016)
\end{itemize}

\item Particularly, \textbf{Location-Based Social Networks (LBSN)} such as \textbf{Twitter} provide opportunities to study spatial dimensions of human behavior (Steiger \textit{et al.}, 2015)

## Introduction

* The potential of LBSN data for studying the way socio-economic and demographic dissimilarity between populations translates to actual segregation was **acknowledged** (Wissink *et al.* 2016) but largely **unrealized**

* Namely, efforts were limited to -
    * Individual regions
    * Semi-qualitative analysis
    * Only considering mobility (physical ties)

## Aim

* Develop and apply **novel spatial network analysis methodology** to evaluate the way that - 
    * Dissimilarity in **population characteristics**
    * Translates to **segregation** – both **physical** and **virtual** – 
    * Between the **geographical areas** those populations occupy

## Objectives

* **Constructing** weighted **networks** representing physical and virtual ties on two distinct spatial scales, based on Twitter
* Fitting models where **tie strength** between given areas is **explained** with - 
    * Geographical distance
    * Socio-economic dissimilarity 
    * Demographic dissimilarity
* Evaluating the **effect size** and **direction** of the effects

## Methods - Network construction

Weighted networks representing **two tie types** – 

* **Follower (virtual) ties** = The number of *follower ties* between a user from area A and a user in area B, divided by the number of potential ties
* **Mobility (physical) ties** = The number of users from area A who have sent at least one tweet when *physically located in area B*, divided by the number of potential ties

On **two spatial scales** –

* **Counties** in the **contiguous USA** (~8,000,000 $km^2$)
* **Census tracts** in **Greater Boston Area** (~50,000 $km^2$)

## Discussion

* Location-Based Social Networks (e.g. Twitter) can be used to map and examine **physical and virtual spatial segregation** in **large-scale human societies**

* Spatial segregation exists in both physical and virtual dimensions, though **weaker in the virtual dimension** due to lower tie formation costs (Wellman & Hampton, 1999)

* Income and age induce **asymmetric segregation** due to the unbalanced motivation of dissimilar populations (Wissink & Hazelzet, 2016)

* The presented methodology can help and **map** the **intangible barriers** for populations movement in physical space and their communication in the virtual one and help **identify** their socio-economic and demographic causes
